name: Biochemistry
description: Within Biological and related sciences, Biochemistry (sometimes called Biological chemistry) is the study of the chemical processes within and relating to living organisms, including living matter.

name: Biological chemistry
description: Focuses on the chemical basis of life, studying the molecules and chemical reactions that occur in living organisms, a core aspect of Biochemistry.

name: Cell technology
description: The application of biological knowledge, particularly at the cellular level, for practical purposes, often involving techniques studied in Biochemistry and biotechnology.

name: Forensic sciences
description: The application of scientific methods and principles to criminal and civil investigations, where biochemical analysis can play a significant role.

name: Genetic code (DNA, RNA) studies
description: The study of deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) and ribonucleic acid (RNA), their structures, functions, and the way they encode genetic information, central to Biochemistry.

name: Genetic engineering
description: The direct manipulation of an organism's genes using biotechnology, a field heavily reliant on principles of Biochemistry.

name: Pharmacology
description: The branch of medicine and biology concerned with the study of drug action, where a drug can be broadly defined as any man-made, natural, or endogenous molecule which exerts a biochemical or physiological effect on the cell, tissue, organ, or organism. This is closely related to Biochemistry.

name: Tissue culture technology
description: Techniques used to grow tissues or cells separate from the organism, often in a laboratory setting, important in Biochemistry and biotechnology.

name: Toxicology
description: The branch of science concerned with the nature, effects, and detection of poisons (toxins), often involving biochemical understanding of their mechanisms.

name: Virology
description: The study of viruses – submicroscopic, parasitic particles of genetic material contained in a protein coat – and virus-like agents. This involves understanding their biochemical nature.
